title: Duke of Cambridge discusses mental health with football fans
text:
The Duke of Cambridge told fellow football fans he is "getting too old" to play 11-aside as he joined them in a south-west London pub to cheer on the England team in their Euro 2020 qualifying game against the Czech Republic.

Arriving at the Prince Albert Pub in Battersea, along with Chelsea manager and ex-England midfielder Frank Lampard, William spoke with several men who shared their personal experiences of mental health problems and football stories.

They celebrated an early goal from Harry Kane, who scored a penalty to take England 1-0 up after barely five minutes, before the Czechs equalised just minutes later.

The visit is part of the new Heads Up campaign, a season-long initiative supported by the charities Mind, Calm, Sporting Chance and Heads Together, which aims to make people, especially men, as comfortable talking about mental health as they are talking about football.

It comes the day after World Mental Health Day, which saw the Duke of Sussex team up with singer Ed Sheeran to make an Instagram video in which the pair urged people to look out for anyone who might be "suffering in silence".

William, president of the Football Association (FA), spoke first to former English professional football player Matt Jansen, who has openly discussed the personal mental health challenges he has faced in the past.
description: The Duke of Cambridge told fellow football fans he is "getting too old" to play 11-aside as he joined them in a south-west London pub to cheer on the England team in their Euro 2020 qualifying game against the Czech Republic.
